awd_titl_txt: Particle Physics at CMS in the High Luminosity Era
awd_abstract_narration:
Particle physics is the study of Nature at its most fundamental level.  Great strides have been made in recent decades, elucidating the key structure of matter and the forces that govern most of the familiar world. Yet more remains unknown and unexplained, and the modern theory of matter and forces, despite its remarkable successes, is thought to be but an approximation to some broader, deeper theory as yet undiscovered.  The dark matter that holds the universe together is unexplained; the masses of fundamental particles are unexplained; even the existence of matter itself is unexplained. This project will both use and extend the capabilities of the large "Compact Muon Solenoid" (CMS) particle detector, which operates at the Large Hadron Collider at the CERN Laboratory in Switzerland, to seek evidence of a larger, more encompassing understanding of the universe and its contents, and in so doing, further the progress of fundamental science.  Much of the research work is done by students, both graduate students and undergraduates, and the education and technical training they receive in this process ensures they can make robust contributions to society.  

Existing and new data produced by the CMS experiment will be studied for possible indications of dark matter production, new heavy bosons, and supersymmetry, as well as for refined measurements of known particles, particularly the top quark, and measurements of as-yet-unobserved processes such as the production of a Higgs boson in conjunction with two top quarks. To extend CMS capabilities, research and development for upgrades to the silicon pixel tracking devices and the trigger will be conducted. Detector upgrades are needed to exploit the full potential of the next accelerator upgrade, known as the High-Luminosity Large Hadron Collider.  Detectors and electronics, together with supporting software and firmware, will be prototyped and studied to establish both the design and construction techniques for the upgrade and to solve the myriad technical challenges that are anticipated.

por.por_cntn:
Particle physics explores the fundamental elements of our universe and seeks to build coherent and predictive descriptions of its findings. In this project we have probed deeply into the vast trove of data generated by the Large Hadron Collider at the CERN Laboratory in Switzerland, looking for possible traces of exotic matter forms.  We know from astrophysical observations that about 80% of the matter in the universe is some strange material, apparently quite different from what we find around us on earth, in our solar system, or in the stars and galaxies we see. This strange stuff is dubbed "dark matter". High energy particle colliders produce a wide variety of particles, and it is possible that occasionally they may produce some dark matter particles.  
We've looked hard for it. But we haven't found it yet.  We've carefully explored several possibilities that haven't been examined in the past, and have drawn clear and quantitative exclusion zones on the "map" of possibilities, ruling out "places" where dark matter might have been hiding -- but where we can now say definitively that it is not.  Like a search team looking for a hiker lost in the woods, we have to be systematic and methodical in covering the map of possible locations, marking off where we have been and where we yet need to go.
Another line of exploration in this project has been to study the characteristics of the "Higgs particle".  This particle, first discovered in the CERN data 7 years ago, is the long-sought corner-stone of the Standard Model of particle physics, and detailed studies of its properties are among the highest priorities of the field.  We have focussed on the possibility that the Higgs particle, which is closely associated with masses of other fundamental particles, should have a special relationship to the heaviest of the six quarks, the top quark.  This is a long term project, and we have so far brought it to the first stage: establishing that we can find examples of the Higgs and the top directly interacting with one another.  This has by itself been a lengthy enterprise with almost a hundred physicists actively engaged in it. In the future, with more data coming in, and more sophisticated detectors to deliver a more detailed picture, we will begin to probe deeply into the workings of the top-Higgs relationship.
Lastly, we have been working to develop those more sophisticated detectors.  These will be particle detectors that can operate efficiently in the much-higher flux of particles that we expect from CERN's next accelerator upgrade, and that can survive the much-higher radiation dose that comes along with the higher flux. We are designing and prototyping the needed electronics, sensors, and structural elements, expecting to deliver final versions in 2026 when the next accelerator upgrade is complete.
